_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction

The Dodge Company (DODGE) is located in Cambridge Massachusetts and has been in business for over 110 years.  Senior management is committed to protecting the health of its employees and the general public and is actively developing comprehensive safety management plans to achieve these objectives.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

DODGE manages the facility in compliance with Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Commonwealth of Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection (MassDEP), and United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) regulations. Senior management at the facility are designated as having primary responsibility for ensuring compliance to these programs.    

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

DODGE provides embalming chemicals for mortuary services.  Raw materials are compounded or mixed at the facility, bottled, stored, and shipped to customers.  The first floor of the facility includes the product mixing and bottling areas, warehouse, chemical storage areas, truck bays, and a shipping room.  Administrative areas, offices, and laboratory space is contained on the second floor. DODGE operates one covered process: warehouse storage.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

DODGE has put in place several measures that serve to prevent/mitigate the release of liquid formaldehyde in the warehouse and shipping areas.  These include:

- Fire extinguishers are located throughout the processing and warehouse areas and personnel that work in these areas have been trained on their proper use.
- Personal protection equipment and spill kits are located throughout the processing and warehouse areas and personnel that work in these areas have been trained on their proper use.
- Warehouse workers are trained in the proper handling of materials, including forklift operation.
- An emergency respo

nse plan has been established with the Cambridge Fire Department.

Five Year Accident History: There have been no reportable releases of formaldehyde at the Dodge Company since it began operations in 1893.

Emergency Response Program: DODGE has a written emergency response plan which has been filed with the Cambridge Fire Department, who is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety: DODGE conducted a process hazards analysis (PHA) for its production processes and warehouse operations in compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation (29 CFR 1910.119). The PHA was based on a what-if question checklist developed through brainstorming and supplemented with unique site-specific issues to ensure that hazards of this process were thoroughly reviewed.  Hazards and applicable recommendations were developed and documented during the PHA.  The recommendations for engineering and administrative (E/A) controls for these scenarios and others identified are documented within the PHA What-If Checklist.
